awd_titl_txt: EAPSI: Catalyst Development for the Synthesis of Acylated Aromatic Compounds
awd_abstract_narration:
Carbon-carbon bond forming reactions are ubiquitous in the realm of synthetic chemistry, allowing the strategic construction of pharmaceuticals and materials alike. Although many methods exist, simple, efficient, and mild conditions are desirable for ease of preparation and economic sustainability.  Metal-catalysts are constantly being developed to satisfy these needs, and the design of new catalysts can provide further progress towards this endeavor. The host researcher, Dr. Tobisu Mamoru at Osaka University, has recently reported a carbon-boron bond forming reaction to yield valuable chemical building blocks. Under Dr. Tobisu?s guidance, the research will optimize the first generation of catalysts for application to carbon-carbon bond formation. This work will lead to the development of synthetic methods useful for the efficient preparation of pharmaceutically relevant acylated aromatics.

This project aims to develop a rhodium catalyst for the mild C-O acylation of pyridyloxy directing groups. Pyridyl directing groups have seen great success in the regioselective C-H activation of aromatic substrates, however, their removal is limiting to their utility in synthetic applications. Dr. Tobisu has recently developed the corresponding C-O borylation reaction, setting the precedent for the proposed transformation. The EAPSI project will allow for the synthesis of acylated aromatics, which are useful intermediates for chemical synthesis and are prevalent among natural products and pharmaceuticals. Development of such catalysts will also further the fundamental understanding of reactivity of rhodium complexes. 

This award under the East Asia and Pacific Summer Institutes program supports summer research by a U.S. graduate student and is funded jointly by NSF and the Japan Society for the Promotion of Science.
org_div_long_name: Office of International Science and Engineering

por.por_cntn:
Carbon–carbon (C–C) bond forming reactions are ubiquitous in the realm of synthetic chemistry, allowing the strategic construction of pharmaceuticals and materials alike. Although many methods exist, simple, efficient, and mild reaction conditions are desirable for ease of preparation and economic sustainability. Transition metal catalysts are constantly being developed to satisfy these needs, and the design of new catalyst systems can provide further progress towards this endeavor.

 

The cross-coupling reaction between carbon-oxygen (C–O) and carbon–hydrogen (C–H) bonds is an appealing process for the straightforward construction of C–C bonds. This project began with the evaluation of a catalyst system known in Professor Tobisu’s laboratory, at Osaka University, which was identified to activate unreactive C–O bonds of readily available phenol derivatives to form carbon–boron bonds. The previously developed catalyst system was ineffective for C–H bond activation, therefore, an investigation into various reaction parameters was performed, which led to the desired reactivity. A variety of strongly electron-donating imidazolium carbene ligands were explored and a sterically encumbered derivative was found to provide the highest yield of the C–C coupled products. Further investigation into the effects of varying both organic and inorganic bases as well as their associated counterions, led to the identification of several inexpensive reagents allowing the transformation to proceed in higher yields. Further attempts to improve the reaction with metal additives did not produce any favorable results. The reaction was found to proceed in both an intermolecular fashion, as well as an intramolecular cyclization variant of the C–C coupling. Finally, attempts were made towards a carbonylative variant for the synthesis of acylated aromatic compounds, however, the newly developed catalyst system was ineffective in furnishing desired product.

 

In addition to the research, this opportunity was a valuable experience for the principle investigator in gaining a new perspective with respect to culture and lifestyle in Japan.

 


Last Modified: 03/11/2017
Modified by: Mikhail O Konev
